subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Williams v. Hays (N.Y. 1899), a ship captain driven insane by overwork crashed his vessel. Is he liable for negligence despite his mental exhaustion?
options: Yes, because self-induced incapacity does not excuse negligence.
No, insanity always negates liability.
Yes, but only if he had notice of his condition.
No, because fatigue is an unforeseeable defense.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Heath v. Swift Wings, Inc. (N.C. 1979), a pilot crashed due to poor technique. What standard of care applied to the professional pilot?
options: The ordinary reasonable person standard.
A heightened professional standard for trained pilots.
No duty applies if the flight was recreational.
A subjective good-faith belief standard.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Fredericks v. Castora (Pa. 1976), both drivers were professional truckers who collided. Can an expert truck driver be held to a higher standard than ordinary drivers?
options: Only if the accident occurred on duty.
Yes, but only if both drivers consented to a professional risk.
No, everyone is judged by the same reasonable person standard.
Yes, professionals are held to a stricter rule in all contexts.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Kerr v. Connecticut Co. (Conn. 1928), a bus driver fainted and crashed. Was the driver negligent for losing consciousness?
options: No, because common carriers owe no special duty.
No, if the fainting was unforeseeable.
Yes, fainting is per se negligent.
Yes, because loss of control always implies negligence.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Davis v. Feinstein (Pa. 1952), a blind man fell into an open cellar he was unaware of. How is the standard of care applied to the visually impaired?
options: Adjusted to what a reasonably prudent blind person would do.
The same as that for a sighted person.
No duty of care applies to disabled pedestrians.
Stricter than ordinary care because blindness is risky.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Purtle v. Shelton (Ark. 1971), a 17-year-old accidentally shot his friend while hunting. What standard applies to minors in adult activities?
options: Reasonable adult standard when engaging in inherently dangerous adult activities.
Immunity under parental supervision.
Strict liability for minors in hunting accidents.
Ordinary child of like age and intelligence.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Roberts v. Ring (Minn. 1919), a 7-year-old ran into the street and was struck by an elderly driver. How is age treated under negligence standards?
options: Children are never contributorily negligent.
Age eliminates liability if under 10 or over 70.
Children and the elderly are both held to objective adult standards.
Children to a child standard; adults to a reasonable adult standard.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Dellwo v. Pearson (Minn. 1961), a 12-year-old operated a motorboat and injured a fisherman. How did the court treat his age?
options: Applied the child standard.
Applied strict liability.
Excused him due to minority.
Applied the adult standard because boating is a dangerous adult activity.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Dunn v. Teti (Pa. 1979), a 6-year-old threw a stick injuring another child. What rule applies to very young children in negligence cases?
options: Children under 7 are incapable of negligence.
They are held to a reasonable child of same age and experience.
Children under 10 are strictly liable.
Negligence depends on parental fault.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Adams v. Bullock (N.Y. 1919), a boy swinging a wire under a trolley bridge was shocked. Why wasn’t the trolley company negligent?
options: The boy assumed the risk.
Electricity is inherently dangerous so strict liability applies.
Contributory negligence barred recovery.
It took reasonable precautions and couldn’t foresee this harm.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Eckert v. Long Island R.R. (N.Y. 1871), a man died saving a child from a train. Was he contributorily negligent?
options: Yes, because self-endangerment is always negligent.
Yes, since the railroad owed no duty to rescuers.
No, rescues are privileged acts.
No, a reasonable rescue is not negligence.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Rodi Yachts, Inc. v. National Marine, Inc. (7th Cir. 1993), a boat was damaged due to concurrent negligence. How did Judge Posner treat comparative fault?
options: Divided damages proportionally to fault.
Held all defendants jointly liable.
Applied contributory negligence bar.
Dismissed because maritime law forbids apportionment.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Brune v. Belinkoff (Mass. 1968), a doctor’s local standard conflicted with national practice. Which standard did the court adopt?
options: Strict liability for medical errors.
National professional standard of care.
Patient’s subjective expectation.
Local custom standard.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Gambill v. Stroud (Ark. 1975), a rural doctor argued for a local standard of care. How did the court treat small-community doctors?
options: Held to a similar-locality standard of professionals in comparable areas.
Judged by national medical standards only.
Strict liability for all patient harm.
Excused due to rural limitation.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Cook v. Irion (Tex. 1966), a lawyer was sued for malpractice. What governs professional negligence standards?
options: Customary local standard only.
Skill and knowledge ordinarily exercised by others in that profession.
Best possible outcome for client.
Strict liability for any error.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Vesely v. Sager (Cal. 1971), a bar served alcohol to a visibly intoxicated patron who caused an accident. What doctrine did this establish?
options: Strict liability for bar owners.
Contributory negligence defense for servers.
Dram shop liability for serving intoxicated persons.
Res ipsa loquitur.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Gorris v. Scott (Eng. 1874), sheep drowned because a carrier violated a statute requiring pens to prevent disease. Why was there no negligence per se?
options: Strict liability applied instead.
The statute aimed to prevent disease, not drowning.
Plaintiff lacked standing.
The violation was minor.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Ross v. Hartman (D.C. Cir. 1944), a truck was left unlocked and stolen, injuring a third party. Why was the owner liable?
options: Leaving keys in vehicle violated a safety statute and was negligence per se.
Criminal acts break causation.
Owner had no duty after theft.
Res ipsa loquitur excused fault.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Tedla v. Ellman (N.Y. 1939), pedestrians walked on the wrong side of the road but avoided danger. What did the court hold?
options: Violation of statute is excused when following it would be more dangerous.
Walking rule only applies at night.
Statutes can be ignored at will.
Violation of statute is always negligence per se.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Theisen v. Milwaukee Automobile Mutual Insurance Co. (Wis. 1963), a driver fell asleep at the wheel. Was he negligent?
options: No, sleep is involuntary.
Yes, but only in commercial driving.
No, because passengers assumed risk.
Yes, falling asleep while driving is negligence unless unforeseeable.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Blaak v. Davidson (Wash. 1978), fog caused a multi-car pileup. How did the court treat limited visibility?
options: Drivers must adjust to conditions; no 'sudden emergency' excuse.
Fog eliminates duty.
Strict liability applies.
Reasonable care only applies to clear weather.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Byrne v. Boadle (Eng. 1863), a barrel fell from a warehouse window injuring a passerby. What doctrine arose?
options: Negligence per se.
Strict liability for all accidents.
Res ipsa loquitur — the thing speaks for itself.
Contributory negligence.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Judson v. Giant Powder Co. (Cal. 1895), an explosion injured neighbors with no clear evidence of fault. What did the court infer?
options: No liability absent direct proof.
The explosion was an act of God.
Plaintiff assumed the risk.
Res ipsa loquitur applied because the defendant controlled the instrumentality.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Archibeque v. Homrich (N.M. 1975), a worker injured by falling rock lacked proof of negligence. How was liability handled?
options: Res ipsa loquitur allowed inference of negligence.
Negligence per se applied.
Plaintiff barred by contributory negligence.
Strict liability imposed automatically.

subject: Torts — Negligence Standard
body: In Ybarra v. Spangard (Cal. 1944), a patient awoke from surgery with an unexplained shoulder injury. What rule applied?
options: Medical malpractice requires direct proof.
Strict liability for hospitals.
Statutory immunity for medical staff.
Res ipsa loquitur — all in control may be held liable absent explanation.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Yania v. Bigan (Pa. 1959), Bigan watched Yania fall into a water-filled trench he had invited him to inspect and made no effort to save him. Was Bigan liable for failing to rescue?
options: No, because Yania was a trespasser.
Yes, moral duty creates legal liability.
Yes, property owners always owe a rescue duty.
No, there is generally no duty to rescue absent a special relationship or creation of the peril.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Soldano v. O’Daniels (Cal. App. 1983), a bartender refused to let a bystander call police from the bar’s phone to prevent a shooting across the street. What did the court hold?
options: The bartender had a duty not to impede rescue efforts.
No duty existed because the harm occurred elsewhere.
Liability only applies to on-premises violence.
The bystander assumed all risk.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Hurley v. Eddingfield (Ind. 1901), a licensed doctor refused to treat a dying patient despite being available. Was there a duty to act?
options: Yes, the doctor–patient relationship imposes duty automatically.
Yes, because medical ethics create enforceable duties.
No, absent a contractual or statutory obligation, a doctor is not legally bound to accept a patient.
No, but only if another doctor was nearby.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In O’Neil v. Montefiore Hospital (N.Y. Sup. 1960), a doctor told a heart patient to return later and the patient died. Why did liability attach?
options: Foreseeability alone creates no duty.
No relationship existed because the doctor was off duty.
Hospitals are immune from volunteer liability.
A doctor-patient relationship was created when the physician undertook to provide care.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In United States v. Lawter (5th Cir. 1963), a Coast Guard rescue helicopter dropped a woman to her death. Why was the government liable?
options: Having undertaken a rescue, the Coast Guard owed a duty to exercise reasonable care.
There was no liability because rescues are discretionary.
The danger was unforeseeable.
Government actors have sovereign immunity.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Frank v. United States (D. Mass. 1962), Coast Guard negligence during a rescue worsened a sailor’s condition. What rule applied?
options: No duty existed because the sailor was already in danger.
Sovereign immunity barred all claims.
Liability only attaches if the rescuer is compensated.
Once a rescue begins, the rescuer must act with reasonable care and not leave the victim worse off.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Bloomberg v. Interinsurance Exchange (Cal. App. 1984), a police dispatcher gave inaccurate information that delayed aid. Why was the dispatcher liable?
options: Government entities owe no duty to individuals.
Emergency services are immune from negligence suits.
Public employees who undertake to act must use reasonable care when others rely on them.
Mere miscommunication creates no liability.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Ocotillo West Joint Venture v. Superior Court (Ariz. App. 1992), a lawyer assured a client that insurance coverage existed when it didn’t. Why did the court find a duty?
options: Statements to clients are never actionable.
There was no privity so no duty.
Professionals owe a duty of reasonable care to foreseeable third parties who rely on their representations.
Duty requires physical injury, not financial harm.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Petition of Trans-Pacific Fishing & Packing Co. v. Howell (9th Cir. 1958), a ship negligently created danger for a crewman during rescue. What did the court emphasize?
options: Shipowners owe no duty beyond contract.
No duty existed because the rescuer assumed risk.
A duty arises when the defendant creates the peril, even if the victim is a volunteer rescuer.
Maritime law eliminates negligence claims.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Charles v. Seigfried (Ill. 1995), a host served alcohol to a minor who later died in a crash. Why was the host not liable?
options: Social hosts owe no common law duty to prevent guests’ self-harm or third-party injury from drinking.
Negligence per se applied automatically.
Minors’ actions break the causal chain.
All providers of alcohol are strictly liable.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Kelly v. Gwinnell (N.J. 1984), an adult host let a visibly intoxicated guest drive and injure another. What duty did the court recognize?
options: Social hosts owe a duty not to serve visibly intoxicated guests who may drive.
Hosts are never liable for guests’ conduct.
Only commercial vendors can be liable.
Duty depends on whether payment occurred.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Tarasoff v. Regents of the University of California (Cal. 1976), therapists failed to warn a victim of a patient’s threat. What duty was imposed?
options: Confidentiality overrides any warning duty.
Only physical proximity creates duty.
The therapist owed no duty to nonpatients.
A mental health professional must warn identifiable victims of foreseeable harm from patients.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Thompson v. County of Alameda (Cal. 1980), a juvenile offender released without warning killed a child. Why no duty?
options: No specific identifiable victim was known; duty requires foreseeability toward a specific person.
Government entities owe no duty to the public.
Releases are discretionary acts immune from review.
Statutory immunity applied automatically.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Kline v. 1500 Massachusetts Avenue Apartment Corp. (D.C. Cir. 1970), repeated assaults occurred in an apartment hallway. What duty did the landlord owe?
options: Absolute insurer of tenant safety.
No duty to protect tenants from third parties.
Only duty to maintain structural soundness.
A landlord must take reasonable precautions against foreseeable criminal acts in common areas.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Bradshaw v. Daniel (Tenn. 1993), a doctor failed to warn a patient’s spouse of contagious disease. What duty was imposed?
options: No duty existed because the harm was indirect.
Public health warnings are government-only duties.
Doctors owe duties only to their patients.
A physician owes a duty to warn identifiable third persons of foreseeable risks of infection.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Hawkins v. Pizarro (Fla. App. 1994), a physician failed to inform a patient that she had hepatitis, leading to harm to another. Why was the doctor liable?
options: No duty existed absent direct relationship.
Liability required statute.
Duty to warn extends to foreseeable third parties exposed to contagious conditions.
Causation broke due to patient negligence.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Riss v. City of New York (N.Y. 1968), police ignored repeated pleas for protection from a stalker who later blinded the victim. What did the court hold?
options: No liability; municipalities are not insurers of public safety absent a special relationship.
City was strictly liable for nonresponse.
Public duty doctrine applies only to federal agencies.
Police owe duty to all citizens equally.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Schuster v. City of New York (N.Y. 1958), police encouraged a citizen to help capture a criminal, and he was later murdered. Why was the city liable?
options: Once the government induces reliance, a special duty arises to protect the informant.
Government never owes duty to individuals.
Volunteers assume all risks.
Statutory immunity applies to informants.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Haskins v. Grybko (Mass. 1946), a landowner accidentally shot a trespasser while hunting on his own land. What duty applied?
options: Duty only if trespasser was a child.
Landowners owe no duty to trespassers except to refrain from willful or wanton harm.
Full duty of reasonable care.
Strict liability for recreational shooting.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Herrick v. Wixom (Mich. 1893), a circus explosion injured spectators outside the tent. What was the duty owed?
options: Strict liability because it was an explosion.
Circus patrons assume all risks.
No duty to those outside the premises.
To exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to invitees and nearby bystanders.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Ehret v. Village of Scarsdale (N.Y. 1934), a worker died of gas leak from a main under a street. What did the court hold?
options: Strict liability applied automatically.
Liability attaches only for gross negligence.
No duty existed for underground utilities.
Municipalities must exercise reasonable care in maintaining gas lines affecting nearby property.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Davies v. McDowell Nat’l Bank (Pa. 1959), tenants died from carbon monoxide in their apartment. Why was the landlord liable?
options: No duty exists for latent defects.
Duty ends when premises are leased.
Owners who invite others owe a duty to warn or fix hidden dangers they know or should know of.
Causation broke due to tenant negligence.

subject: Torts — Duty
body: In Rowland v. Christian (Cal. 1968), a guest was injured by a broken faucet handle. How did this change landowner duty law?
options: Abolished the rigid invitee/licensee/trespasser distinctions in favor of a general duty of reasonable care.
Limited duty to invited social guests only.
Imposed strict liability for home defects.
Reaffirmed traditional classifications.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In New York Central R.R. v. Grimstad (2d Cir. 1920), a barge captain fell overboard and drowned because there was no life buoy nearby. Why did the widow lose?
options: Contributory negligence barred recovery.
She could not prove that having a life buoy would have saved him—causation was speculative.
Negligence per se applied automatically.
The railroad was immune under maritime law.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Gardner v. National Bulk Carriers, Inc. (4th Cir. 1962), a ship failed to turn back after a sailor fell overboard. Why was the company liable?
options: A reasonable search would probably have saved the sailor, establishing factual causation.
The sailor assumed the risk by going overboard.
Ships owe no duty to lost crewmen.
Causation was broken by ocean currents.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Stacy v. Knickerbocker Ice Co. (Wis. 1893), horses broke through thin ice and drowned after being sent onto an unsafe pond. What was the causal issue?
options: No duty existed for animals.
Defendant’s act directly caused the loss; foreseeability was irrelevant for factual causation.
Intervening acts broke the chain.
Plaintiff’s negligence was the only cause.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Haft v. Lone Palm Hotel (Cal. 1970), a father and son drowned in a motel pool without a lifeguard. Why did the court shift the burden of proof?
options: Because defendant’s negligence made it impossible to prove how the deaths occurred, the burden of causation shifted.
Res ipsa loquitur never applies to drowning.
No liability absent eyewitness testimony.
Plaintiff had to prove causation directly.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Bernard v. Char (Haw. 1995), a doctor delayed cancer diagnosis by months. Why did plaintiff still recover?
options: Medical misdiagnosis cannot be causal absent death.
Expert testimony is irrelevant to causation.
Causation requires proof of more-likely-than-not survival.
Loss-of-chance doctrine allows recovery for reduction in survival probability due to negligence.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Canterbury v. Spence (D.C. Cir. 1972), a patient wasn’t warned of paralysis risk before surgery. How was causation proven in informed consent?
options: By proving the doctor intended harm.
Expert testimony alone determines consent.
Causation is presumed in all nondisclosure cases.
By showing a reasonable patient would have declined the procedure if informed.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Scott v. Bradford (Okla. 1979), a woman suffered complications after a hysterectomy without adequate warning. What rule applied?
options: Doctors are liable if a reasonable patient would have refused had they been warned.
Liability depends only on doctor’s intent.
Informed consent doesn’t apply to common procedures.
Causation fails if the surgery was beneficial.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Zalazar v. Vercimak (Ill. App. 1993), a delayed appendicitis diagnosis worsened the outcome. What causal standard was debated?
options: Whether negligence per se applied automatically.
Whether doctor-patient duty existed.
Whether comparative fault applied.
Whether negligent delay increased risk of harm sufficiently to count as a factual cause.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Herskovits v. Group Health Cooperative (Wash. 1983), negligent diagnosis reduced a lung cancer patient’s survival chance from 39% to 25%. What did the court allow?
options: Causation presumed whenever death results.
Loss-of-chance recovery recognizing reduced survival probability as compensable harm.
No recovery absent >50% probability of survival.
Strict liability for all diagnostic errors.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Cooper v. Sisters of Charity of Cincinnati (Ohio 1971), a delayed C-section allegedly caused brain damage. What did the court require?
options: Proof of any reduction in survival chance.
Proof that negligence more likely than not caused injury.
Expert testimony that negligence occurred.
Statutory presumption of causation.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Dumas v. Cooney (Cal. App. 1991), failure to diagnose cancer was alleged to reduce life expectancy. Why did the claim fail?
options: Death breaks all causation chains.
Statute barred all medical suits.
Loss-of-chance applied automatically.
Plaintiff could not prove causation by preponderance of evidence.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Fennell v. Southern Maryland Hospital (Md. 1990), experts disagreed on whether earlier treatment would save the patient. What principle governed?
options: Expert uncertainty favors plaintiff.
Probable, not possible, causation required for liability.
Burden shifts to defendant in medical cases.
Possibility of benefit is enough for recovery.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Wendland v. Sparks (Iowa 1998), a man was killed after electrical repairs failed inspection. What was the factual issue?
options: Whether negligent inspection was a substantial factor in causing electrocution.
Whether punitive damages apply automatically.
Whether foreseeability affects factual cause.
Whether strict liability supersedes negligence.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Frye v. United States (D.C. Cir. 1923), the court excluded polygraph evidence. What causal-proof lesson emerged?
options: Any novel science is admissible if relevant.
Scientific evidence must be generally accepted before used to establish causation.
Juries decide scientific reliability alone.
Causation is presumed from expert testimony.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals (U.S. 1993), plaintiffs alleged birth defects from a drug. What standard replaced Frye?
options: Peer review alone guarantees admissibility.
Judges must act as gatekeepers ensuring scientific validity and relevance of expert testimony.
Daubert eliminated expert testimony in torts.
All expert evidence is admissible for jury evaluation.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Summers v. Tice (Cal. 1948), two hunters negligently fired, one hit plaintiff, but it was unclear who. What rule emerged?
options: Joint and several liability is abolished.
Res ipsa loquitur applies automatically.
Plaintiff must prove exact cause.
Alternative liability—burden shifts to defendants to prove who caused the harm.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Sindell v. Abbott Laboratories (Cal. 1980), DES manufacturers couldn’t be linked to plaintiff’s ingestion. What doctrine applied?
options: Market-share liability, apportioning responsibility by market share.
No liability absent proof of product identity.
Joint liability only for identified producers.
Strict liability barred by statute.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Sanderson v. International Flavors & Fragrances (C.D. Cal. 1996), workers exposed to chemicals couldn’t identify the supplier. What happened?
options: Strict liability applied automatically.
Statute created automatic causation presumption.
Burden shifted to defendants.
Court declined to extend market-share liability beyond DES context.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Smith v. Cutter Biological (Haw. 1991), hemophiliacs contracted HIV from contaminated plasma. How was causation treated?
options: Market-share rule applied automatically.
Res ipsa loquitur supplied causation.
All producers share liability equally.
Plaintiff must identify which manufacturer’s product caused infection.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Kingston v. Chicago & N.W. Ry. (Wis. 1927), two fires merged destroying plaintiff’s property. What rule applied?
options: No liability because of multiple sources.
Causation fails where two independent fires combine.
Strict liability for all fires.
Each negligent cause sufficient to produce the harm is a factual cause.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Corey v. Havener (Mass. 1902), two motorcyclists frightened a horse, injuring rider. What causation rule emerged?
options: Plaintiff must apportion fault precisely.
Concurrent negligent acts causing a single injury make both actors jointly liable.
Strict liability for motorcyclists only.
No liability absent contact.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Anderson v. Minneapolis Railway (Minn. 1920), two fires (one natural, one negligent) merged. What did the court hold?
options: Strict liability governs all fires.
Plaintiff must prove exclusive cause.
Defendant liable if its negligence was a substantial factor in producing the harm.
Causation fails when natural events intervene.

subject: Torts — Cause-in-Fact
body: In Kramer Service, Inc. v. Wilkins (Miss. 1939), a man developed cancer after glass cut his head. What principle was clarified?
options: Statutory presumption controls causation.
Cut injuries always lead to cancer.
Possibility is not enough; causation requires probability.
Expert speculation suffices.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In In re Polemis (Eng. 1921), a plank was negligently dropped into a ship’s hold, igniting vapors and causing an explosion. What did the court decide?
options: Liability limited to foreseeable harms.
Shipowner assumed the risk.
Intervening explosion broke causation.
Defendant liable for all direct consequences of negligence, even if unforeseeable.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Overseas Tankship (The Wagon Mound No. 1) (Privy Council 1961), oil spilled in a harbor and later ignited. How did this revise Polemis?
options: Liability only for foreseeable consequences of negligence.
Liability for all direct consequences.
Res ipsa loquitur determined fault.
Strict liability for oil spills.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Petition of Kinsman Transit Co. (2d Cir. 1964), an unmoored ship drifted and destroyed a bridge. What rule did Judge Friendly apply?
options: Defendant liable only to immediate neighbors.
Liability extends to all resulting harm, foreseeable or not.
Liability extends to foreseeable types of harm, even if magnitude or manner is unusual.
Strict liability applies to maritime collisions.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Doughty v. Turner Manufacturing (U.K. 1964), a cover fell into a vat causing an unforeseeable chemical eruption. Why no liability?
options: Any industrial injury is foreseeable.
Contributory negligence barred recovery.
The specific mechanism of harm was unforeseeable; only splashing was foreseeable.
Res ipsa loquitur supplied proximate cause.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Colonial Inn Motor Lodge v. Gay (Ill. App. 1997), a car crashed into a motel after driver fainted. What was the issue?
options: Res ipsa loquitur applied automatically.
Whether the motel’s design foreseeably increased the risk of impact.
Whether fainting was unforeseeable.
Strict liability for design defects.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In DiPonzio v. Riordan (N.Y. 1997), a gas station customer left his car running and it rolled into another. Why no liability for the station?
options: Comparative fault eliminates duty.
Gas stations are strictly liable for rolling cars.
Intervening acts always break causation.
The harm was outside the scope of the station’s safety rule—foreseeability limited duty and causation.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In United Novelty Co. v. Daniels (Miss. 1949), gasoline fumes ignited from a monkey’s match while cleaning machines. Why liable?
options: Animals break the causal chain.
Negligence created foreseeable risk of ignition; bizarre details don’t defeat proximate cause.
Intervening acts always bar recovery.
No duty to protect employees.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Steinhauser v. Hertz Corp. (2d Cir. 1970), a minor collision triggered plaintiff’s latent psychosis. Why did causation hold?
options: Emotional injuries must be foreseeable.
Only physical injuries are compensable.
Defendant takes plaintiff as found; thin skull rule applies to mental harm as well.
No causation because illness was preexisting.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Central of Georgia Ry. v. Price (Ga. 1898), a lamp negligently provided in a hotel room exploded. Why was railroad not liable?
options: Foreseeability extended to all property damage.
Plaintiff’s assumption of risk broke causation.
Independent hotel negligence was a superseding cause.
Railroad owed a nondelegable duty.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Pridham v. Cash & Carry Building Center (N.H. 1976), plaintiff was injured when ambulance crashed en route to hospital. What did the court hold?
options: Subsequent accidents always supersede.
Negligent actor liable for additional harm during normal rescue or medical transport.
Ambulance drivers are independent intervenors.
Only medical malpractice breaks causation.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Berry v. Borough of Sugar Notch (Pa. 1899), a motorman speeding through a storm was hit by a falling tree. Why no liability?
options: Speeding always bars recovery.
The harm (tree fall) was not within the risk created by speeding.
Strict liability applied automatically.
Contributory negligence was absolute.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Brauer v. New York Central R.R. (N.J. 1918), thieves stole goods after a collision caused by defendant. Why was the railroad liable?
options: Only direct physical injury counts.
Railroads have immunity from theft claims.
Negligent defendant liable for foreseeable third-party criminal acts during immediate aftermath.
Criminal acts always supersede negligence.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Watson v. Kentucky & Indiana Bridge Co. (Ky. 1910), an explosion occurred after gasoline spill ignited. What test applied?
options: All intervening acts supersede.
Foreseeability irrelevant to proximate cause.
If intervening act was malicious, it supersedes; if negligent, it may not.
Strict liability governs all explosions.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Village of Carterville v. Cook (Ill. 1889), a defective sidewalk caused a horse to bolt and injure plaintiff. Why liable?
options: Animal reactions are superseding causes.
Injury was foreseeable consequence of defective public walkway.
Strict liability replaced negligence.
Municipalities owe no duty to riders.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Alexander v. Town of New Castle (Ind. 1888), a fire started by sparks from a train spread to plaintiff’s barn. Why liable?
options: Defendant responsible for all foreseeable spread of fire from its negligence.
Fires are acts of God once spreading.
Only the first building’s loss recoverable.
Railroads have statutory immunity.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Scott v. Shepherd (Eng. 1773, The Squib Case), a lit squib was thrown through a market causing injuries. What principle arose?
options: Intervening throws break the causal chain.
Continuous chain of causation preserves liability despite intervening reactions made under compulsion.
Res ipsa loquitur applied automatically.
Each actor liable only for their own toss.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In The Roman Prince (S.D.N.Y. 1921), negligent loading caused a ship to list and crush a worker. Why liable?
options: Causation limited to direct property harm.
Negligent loading foreseeably endangered dockworkers within zone of risk.
Proximate cause ends at the ship’s deck.
Maritime employers immune from negligence.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In White v. Manhattan & Bronx Surface Transit Auth. (N.Y. 1978), a passenger had a heart attack after bus stopped suddenly. Why no liability?
options: Strict liability for carriers applies.
Harm was unforeseeable and outside risk of sudden stop.
Heart attacks are presumed foreseeable.
Any physical reaction creates liability.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Johnson v. Kosmos Portland Cement Co. (6th Cir. 1933), lightning ignited vapors left in a barge. Why liable?
options: Maritime law bars recovery for explosions.
Lightning cannot be foreseeable.
Negligent storage of explosive vapors made lightning a foreseeable igniter.
Acts of God always supersede negligence.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Henry v. Houston Lighting & Power Co. (Tex. App. 1996), a power line arced when struck by a crane. Why liable?
options: Power company failed to insulate foreseeable contact zones.
Comparative negligence eliminated fault.
Strict liability barred recovery.
Intervening contractor misuse broke causation.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Bell v. Campbell (Tex. 1968), a second car crash occurred while clearing the first accident scene. Why no liability for first driver?
options: Defendants share joint proximate cause.
The second crash was an independent, superseding cause.
All subsequent harm flows from initial negligence.
Foreseeability irrelevant after first impact.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. (N.Y. 1928), guards pushed a passenger whose package exploded, injuring a bystander. What did Cardozo hold?
options: Negligence to one is negligence to all.
Strict liability applies for explosives.
Causation extends indefinitely.
Defendant owes duty only to those within the reasonably foreseeable zone of danger.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Ryan v. New York Central R.R. (N.Y. 1866), fire spread from a shed to several houses. Why limited liability?
options: Contributory negligence applied.
All spread fires are foreseeable.
Only the first adjoining property’s damage was foreseeable; remote losses too attenuated.
Railroads strictly liable for fire spread.

subject: Torts — Proximate Cause
body: In Wagon Mound No. 2 (Privy Council 1967), workers ignored oil slicks before welding. What was the holding?
options: Even a small foreseeable risk of serious harm triggers liability when reasonable precautions exist.
Liability only for highly probable risks.
Intervening negligence breaks causation.
Strict liability for all oil fires.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Behrens v. Bertram Mills Circus, Ltd. (U.K. 1957), an elephant frightened a dog that bit its owner. Why was the circus liable?
options: Circuses owe only reasonable care, not strict liability.
Contributory negligence bars strict liability.
Elephant behavior was unforeseeable, eliminating liability.
Owners of wild animals are strictly liable for harm characteristic of the species.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Lossee v. Buchanan (N.Y. 1873), a steam boiler exploded, injuring a neighbor. Why no strict liability?
options: Law limited liability to negligence for socially useful activities.
Res ipsa loquitur established negligence conclusively.
All explosive operations are automatically liable.
Plaintiff assumed the risk of industrial noise.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Turner v. Big Lake Oil Co. (Tex. 1936), oil escaped from storage tanks and damaged neighboring land. Why did Texas reject Rylands v. Fletcher?
options: Because Rylands applies only to explosives.
Because contributory negligence barred recovery.
Because water and oil storage were ordinary, not unnatural uses of land in Texas.
Because all oil extraction was ultrahazardous.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Lubin v. Iowa City (Iowa 1962), a buried water main burst and flooded property. Why was the city strictly liable?
options: Causation required proof of negligence.
Municipal utilities are immune from strict liability.
Maintaining a pressurized water system created foreseeable risk of escape and harm.
Liability only arises after notice of defect.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Walker Shoe Store v. Howard’s Hobby Shop (Mo. App. 1963), fireworks exploded next door. What was the holding?
options: Retailers enjoy immunity for government-approved goods.
Liability depends on comparative fault.
Negligence must still be proven in urban settings.
Storage of fireworks is an abnormally dangerous activity invoking strict liability.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Indiana Harbor Belt R.R. v. American Cyanamid Co. (7th Cir. 1990), chemicals leaked during transport. What did Judge Posner hold?
options: Federal preemption bars tort claims.
Transport of toxic chemicals is always ultrahazardous.
Railroads automatically bear strict liability.
Strict liability does not apply if negligence could prevent the harm effectively.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Kuhlman v. City of Detroit (Mich. App. 1973), sewer explosion caused damage. Why liable?
options: Pressurized sewer maintenance involved abnormal risk and justified strict liability.
Acts of God excluded liability.
Municipalities are immune from all strict liability.
Negligence must be shown for sewer systems.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Pyrodyne Corp. v. Pierce County (Wash. 1991), fireworks injured spectators at a public display. What doctrine applied?
options: Only negligence applies to licensed pyrotechnicians.
Governmental immunity barred all claims.
Contributory negligence defeated liability.
Public fireworks are abnormally dangerous activities subject to strict liability.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Miller v. Civil Constructors, Inc. (Ill. App. 1995), stray bullets from a police training range injured nearby residents. Why no strict liability?
options: Risk magnitude overrides social utility.
All shooting ranges are ultrahazardous.
Police firearm training is not abnormally dangerous because risk can be reduced by care.
Negligence per se applied automatically.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Sullivan v. Dunham (N.Y. 1900), dynamite used to remove a tree killed a passerby. What principle arose?
options: Use of explosives imposes strict liability for harm to persons or property.
Negligence must be proven for lawful blasting.
Plaintiff assumed the risk by walking nearby.
Foreseeability determines liability.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Madsen v. East Jordan Irrigation Co. (Utah 1942), an explosion frightened mink who killed their young. Why no liability?
options: Psychological effects trigger strict liability.
Animals are unforeseeable intervenors but still compensable.
Strict liability extends to all consequential harms.
The harm was too remote and unforeseeable from the dangerous activity.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Rylands v. Fletcher (U.K. 1868), a reservoir burst flooding mines. What foundational rule was created?
options: Landowners owe only reasonable care.
Strict liability applies only to commercial uses.
Liability only when negligence is proven.
A person who brings something likely to escape onto land is strictly liable for resulting harm.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Klein v. Pyrodyne Corp. (Wash. 1991), fireworks injured spectators at a public display. What did the court emphasize?
options: Assumption of risk bars strict liability.
Public entertainment immunity applied.
Licensed pyrotechnicians conducting public displays engage in abnormally dangerous activity.
Fireworks injuries always require negligence.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Siegler v. Kuhlman (Wash. 1973), gasoline truck exploded after overturning. Why strict liability applied?
options: Transporting large quantities of flammable liquid creates high risk even with utmost care.
Commercial trucking preempts state tort law.
Plaintiff’s negligence superseded.
Causation uncertain eliminates liability.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Yommer v. McKenzie (Md. 1969), gasoline leaked into a well. What did the court find?
options: Environmental harm not compensable under tort.
Strict liability applies only to explosives.
Gasoline storage in residential areas is abnormally dangerous.
Negligence must still be proven.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Green v. General Petroleum Corp. (Cal. 1928), oil well blowout sprayed property with oil. What was decided?
options: Negligence standard controlled because oil is useful.
Oil drilling exempt from strict liability.
Strict liability applied for damage from industrial operations involving abnormally high risk.
Plaintiff assumed risk by living nearby.

subject: Torts — Strict Liability
body: In Spano v. Perini Corp. (N.Y. 1969), blasting operations damaged a garage. Why liable without negligence?
options: Proof of negligence required for lawful blasting.
Plaintiff’s consent implied by proximity.
Foreseeability bars liability.
Blasting is an inherently dangerous activity invoking strict liability for resulting damage.

subject: Criminal Law — Purposes of Punishment
body: In Regina v. Dudley and Stephens (1884), sailors killed and ate a cabin boy to survive. What principle did the court emphasize?
options: Retributive justice always outweighs deterrence.
Proportional punishment justifies the act.
Necessity is not a defense to intentional homicide.
Survival necessity excuses murder.

subject: Criminal Law — Legality Principle
body: In Commonwealth v. Mochan (1955), obscene phone calls led to conviction under no specific statute. The decision illustrates a violation of which doctrine?
options: Vagueness in mental state.
Retroactivity in punishment.
Legality — no punishment without preexisting law.
Proportionality in sentencing.

subject: Criminal Law — Vagueness
body: Papachristou v. City of Jacksonville (1972) invalidated a vagrancy ordinance because it violated what constitutional protection?
options: Separation of powers — excessive delegation.
Eighth Amendment — excessive punishment.
Equal Protection — the law discriminated on race.
Due Process — the law was unconstitutionally vague.

subject: Criminal Law — Actus Reus
body: In Martin v. State (1944), police dragged an intoxicated man into public where he was arrested for public drunkenness. Why was he acquitted?
options: Police entrapment applies to all coercion.
The statute did not cover private intoxication.
He lacked mens rea for intoxication.
A voluntary act is required for criminal liability.

subject: Criminal Law — Omissions
body: People v. Beardsley (1907) held a man not guilty for failing to aid his mistress who overdosed because?
options: The act was impossible to perform.
The victim consented to inaction.
No legal duty existed to act absent a special relationship.
Moral duty always suffices.

subject: Criminal Law — Possession
body: In United States v. Maldonado (1996), the defendant left drugs in a hotel room. What mental element is required for possession?
options: Knowing dominion and control over the object.
Mere proximity.
Motive to distribute.
Intent to conceal.

subject: Criminal Law — Mens Rea (Common Law)
body: Regina v. Cunningham (1957) defined 'malice' as what?
options: Either intention or recklessness as to the prohibited harm.
Hatred or ill will toward the victim.
Strict liability for dangerous acts.
Gross negligence regardless of awareness.

subject: Criminal Law — Transferred Intent
body: In Regina v. Faulkner (1877), a sailor lit rum while stealing it and accidentally burned a ship. What rule emerged?
options: Negligence suffices for arson.
Mens rea must relate to the charged offense.
Transferred intent applies across all felonies.
Intent to steal equals intent to burn.

subject: Criminal Law — Strict Liability
body: United States v. Balint (1922) upheld strict liability for drug distribution because?
options: The defendants were negligent.
Due process forbids mental element removal.
Congress may impose liability without mens rea in public welfare offenses.
Motive determines culpability.

subject: Criminal Law — Mistake of Fact
body: Regina v. Prince (1875) convicted a man who reasonably believed a girl was 18 when she was under 16. Why?
options: He acted negligently.
Mistake of fact was no defense because the act was morally wrong.
Strict liability applied to all sexual offenses.
He failed to verify identity.

subject: Criminal Law — Mistake of Law
body: People v. Marrero (1987) denied a defense to a federal corrections officer who misread a gun law. Why?
options: Good faith reliance always excuses error.
Ambiguity in statutes nullifies guilt.
Mistake of law is not a defense unless reliance on an official statement.
Ignorance of law negates intent.

subject: Criminal Law — Intoxication
body: Regina v. Majewski (1977) held voluntary intoxication is no defense to what type of crimes?
options: Specific intent crimes.
General intent crimes.
Involuntary manslaughter only.
Strict liability offenses.

subject: Criminal Law — Attempt
body: People v. Rizzo (1927) held defendants not guilty of attempted robbery because?
options: The victims were not harmed.
They abandoned the plan voluntarily.
They had not come dangerously close to completing the crime.
They lacked intent.

subject: Criminal Law — Attempt under MPC
body: State v. Reeves (1996) held two middle-schoolers guilty of attempt for poison plans. Why?
options: Overt act must be completed.
Intent must be conditional.
Substantial step toward commission suffices under MPC §5.01.
Abandonment always excuses liability.

subject: Criminal Law — Impossibility
body: People v. Jaffe (1906) held a defendant not guilty for buying stolen goods that were not stolen. Why?
options: Mistake of fact always excuses.
Strict liability applies to attempt.
Legal impossibility is a defense; factual impossibility is not.
All impossibility is irrelevant.

subject: Criminal Law — Solicitation
body: State v. Cotton (1990) involved letters urging sexual abuse. Why was the solicitation charge reversed?
options: Communication was intercepted before reaching the intended recipient.
The letters were ambiguous.
The intent was unproven.
Solicitation requires an overt act.

subject: Criminal Law — Conspiracy
body: United States v. Alvarez (1991) clarified conspiracy liability requires what?
options: Completion of the crime.
Performance of an overt act by all parties.
Agreement and intent to achieve the unlawful objective.
Proof of motive.

subject: Criminal Law — Felony Murder
body: People v. Stamp (1969) held defendants liable for a victim’s heart attack after robbery. Why?
options: The victim’s frailty is a defense.
Malice must be proven separately.
Felony murder applies even to unforeseeable deaths during felonies.
Negligence replaced intent.

subject: Criminal Law — Provocation
body: Girouard v. State (1991) held words alone were insufficient provocation because?
options: Cooling-off was irrelevant.
Only legally adequate provocations can mitigate murder to manslaughter.
Verbal insults negate malice automatically.
MPC treats all killings as provoked.

subject: Criminal Law — Depraved Heart Murder
body: Commonwealth v. Malone (1946) upheld murder for a game of Russian roulette. Why?
options: Victim’s consent bars liability.
Intent to kill is required.
Negligence suffices for murder.
Extreme recklessness showing indifference to human life suffices for malice.

subject: Criminal Law — Negligent Homicide
body: People v. Hall (2000) convicted a skier after reckless downhill conduct. What distinguishes recklessness from negligence?
options: Negligence requires awareness of risk.
Neither considers foreseeability.
Both require intent to harm.
Recklessness requires conscious disregard of a known risk.

subject: Criminal Law — Insanity Defense
body: M’Naghten’s Case (1843) defined insanity as lack of what?
options: Emotional control.
Volition to act.
Understanding of the nature or wrongfulness of the act.
Ability to resist temptation.

subject: Criminal Law — MPC Insanity
body: Under the MPC test, a defendant is not responsible if they lack what capacity?
options: Total incapacity to reason.
Motive to act lawfully.
Substantial capacity to appreciate criminality or conform conduct to law.
Ability to recall consequences.

subject: Criminal Law — Duress
body: United States v. Contento-Pachon (1984) allowed duress for cocaine smuggling because?
options: Economic pressure sufficed.
Fear of prosecution counts as coercion.
Defendant created the risk himself.
Threats were imminent, serious, and left no reasonable escape.

subject: Criminal Law — Necessity
body: United States v. Bailey (1980) limited the necessity defense for prisoners who escaped because?
options: They failed to surrender once the danger passed.
All prison escapes are per se justified.
They acted in self-defense.
Necessity applies to duress only.

subject: Contracts — Consideration
body: In Hamer v. Sidway (1891), an uncle promised $5,000 if his nephew refrained from drinking and smoking until age 21. What did the court hold constituted valid consideration?
options: Moral obligation.
Forbearance of a legal right.
Natural love and affection.
Nominal payment of $1.

subject: Contracts — Objective Theory of Assent
body: In Lucy v. Zehmer (1954), why did the court enforce a barroom agreement to sell land even though the seller claimed it was a joke?
options: Consideration was presumed.
Jokes are enforceable when written down.
Land sales require subjective intent.
Intent is judged by outward expressions, not secret intent.

subject: Contracts — Implied in Fact
body: Bailey v. West (1969) involved care of a racehorse by mistake. Why was there no implied-in-fact contract?
options: The plaintiff acted as a volunteer.
There was no mutual assent between the parties.
The benefit conferred was substantial.
The defendant failed to object promptly.

subject: Contracts — Damages
body: In Jacob & Youngs v. Kent (1921), the builder used the wrong brand of pipe. What rule did the court adopt for recovery?
options: Strict compliance with contract terms.
Substantial performance with damages for the difference in value.
Restitution for partial performance.
Specific performance of replacement.

subject: Contracts — Specific Performance
body: Walker v. Keith (1964) refused to enforce a renewal option because what was missing?
options: The parties lacked capacity.
The subject matter was land.
Essential terms were too indefinite.
The price term was fair.

subject: Contracts — Economic Inequality
body: In Williams v. Walker-Thomas Furniture Co. (1965), the court remanded to determine whether what doctrine applied?
options: Duress.
Unconscionability under UCC §2-302.
Mutual mistake.
Fraud in the inducement.

subject: Contracts — Gratuitous Promises
body: Kirksey v. Kirksey (1845) denied enforcement of a brother-in-law’s invitation to move to his land because why?
options: It was an illusory promise.
It violated the Statute of Frauds.
It was void for vagueness.
It was a mere gratuitous promise without consideration.

subject: Contracts — Nominal Consideration
body: In re Greene (1930) involved a gift disguised as a contract. Why was the promise unenforceable?
options: The consideration was nominal and not bargained-for.
The parties lacked capacity.
The promise violated public policy.
The agreement was oral.

subject: Contracts — Adequacy of Consideration
body: Batsakis v. Demotsis (1949) held that even unequal bargains are enforceable if what is present?
options: A bargained-for exchange of value.
Fair market equivalence.
Economic duress.
Nominal consideration.

subject: Contracts — Moral Obligation
body: In Webb v. McGowin (1935), why was a promise to pay upheld after the promisor was saved from harm?
options: Consideration was implied by law.
Moral obligation alone suffices.
The promise was under seal.
A material benefit received can support a subsequent promise.

subject: Contracts — Promissory Estoppel
body: Ricketts v. Scothorn (1898) enforced a grandfather’s promise based on what principle?
options: Moral obligation alone suffices.
Written form required enforcement.
Reliance to the promisee’s detriment can substitute for consideration.
The promise was conditional.

subject: Contracts — Promissory Estoppel
body: Feinberg v. Pfeiffer Co. (1959) held that a retirement promise was binding because?
options: The promise was nominally sealed.
The employee relied on it to her detriment by retiring.
The company intended a gift.
Public policy required fairness.

subject: Contracts — Reliance Damages
body: Hoffman v. Red Owl Stores (1965) granted damages to a party who relied on preliminary promises. Why?
options: Quasi-contract applies to all dealings.
All negotiations are binding once begun.
Preliminary agreements are enforceable per se.
Promissory estoppel protects reliance even absent a full contract.

subject: Contracts — Charitable Subscription
body: Allegheny College (1927) found consideration in a gift to a college because?
options: Moral duty sufficed.
The donor imposed a condition creating a bilateral obligation.
Charitable intent was presumed.
Nominal payment was given.

subject: Contracts — Offer & Acceptance
body: Lefkowitz v. Great Minneapolis Surplus Store (1957) held an ad to sell fur coats was an offer because?
options: The store breached fiduciary duty.
It was labeled as an offer.
It was clear, definite, and left nothing open for negotiation.
The buyer was a prior customer.

subject: Contracts — Mirror Image Rule
body: In Ardente v. Horan (1976), why was the buyer’s acceptance ineffective?
options: It added conditions, making it a counteroffer.
It lacked consideration.
It was oral rather than written.
It was revoked by mail.

subject: Contracts — Mutual Mistake
body: Sherwood v. Walker (1887) voided a sale of a cow when both believed it was barren but it was fertile. Why?
options: Contract law excludes agricultural goods.
Mutual mistake about a basic assumption voids consent.
All animal sales are conditional.
Unilateral mistake is never excused.

subject: Contracts — Parol Evidence Rule
body: Masterson v. Sine (1968) allowed parol evidence of a buyback clause because?
options: The deed was not intended as a complete integration.
Parol evidence always controls oral terms.
Fraud was alleged.
It violated no statute.

subject: Contracts — Statute of Frauds
body: Klewin v. Flagship Properties (1985) addressed long-term oral contracts. What rule emerged?
options: All real estate deals require notaries.
Contracts not performable within a year require writing under the Statute of Frauds.
Parol evidence may cure missing signatures.
Reliance removes the writing requirement.

subject: Contracts — Remedies
body: Hadley v. Baxendale (1854) limited damages to what type of losses?
options: Nominal damages only.
Foreseeable losses at the time of contract formation.
All consequential losses regardless of notice.
Punitive damages for breach.

subject: Contracts — Efficient Breach
body: Peevyhouse v. Garland Coal (1963) awarded only diminished value damages because?
options: Restoration clauses are void.
Mining contracts are unenforceable.
Plaintiff failed to mitigate.
The cost of performance was grossly disproportionate to its value.

subject: Contracts — Expectation Damages
body: Freund v. Washington Square Press (1974) awarded nominal damages because?
options: Lost royalties were too speculative.
The contract was illegal.
The author rescinded early.
The publisher acted in good faith.

subject: Contracts — Modification
body: Alaska Packers’ Ass’n v. Domenico (1902) held a mid-performance wage increase unenforceable because?
options: Public policy forbade it.
Workers were minors.
The contract was oral.
There was no new consideration for the modification.

subject: Contracts — Excuse by Impossibility
body: Krell v. Henry (1903) excused payment for a room rental because?
options: The promise was illegal.
The coronation’s cancellation frustrated the contract’s principal purpose.
Weather made performance costly.
The building was destroyed.

subject: Civil Procedure — Personal Jurisdiction
body: In Pennoyer v. Neff (1877), a state court issued a judgment against a nonresident who had never been served within the forum. What principle did the Court establish?
options: Quasi in rem jurisdiction is unrestricted.
Federal courts can override state boundaries for service.
Constructive notice by publication is always sufficient.
Jurisdiction requires personal service within the forum or consent.

subject: Civil Procedure — Personal Jurisdiction
body: In International Shoe Co. v. Washington (1945), the Court replaced territorial power with which modern test for jurisdiction?
options: Complete diversity requirement.
Tag jurisdiction based on presence.
Domicile and consent only.
Purposeful availment and minimum contacts.

subject: Civil Procedure — Personal Jurisdiction
body: World-Wide Volkswagen v. Woodson (1980) held that foreseeability alone does not confer jurisdiction unless what is shown?
options: Plaintiff’s injury was foreseeable anywhere.
A federal statute authorizes nationwide service.
The defendant purposefully directed activities at the forum.
There was a contractual relationship.

subject: Civil Procedure — Personal Jurisdiction
body: In Burger King Corp. v. Rudzewicz (1985), why did the Court uphold Florida’s jurisdiction over a Michigan franchisee?
options: The contract created continuing obligations with Florida.
The franchise was incorporated in Florida.
The defendant traveled to Florida for negotiations.
Florida had a long-arm statute covering all torts.

subject: Civil Procedure — General Jurisdiction
body: Daimler AG v. Bauman (2014) narrowed general jurisdiction to which locations?
options: Wherever harm occurs.
Wherever the company has continuous sales.
Place of incorporation and principal place of business.
Any state where the company sells products.

subject: Civil Procedure — Specific Jurisdiction
body: In Ford Motor Co. v. Montana (2021), the Court held jurisdiction was proper because the claims were what?
options: Filed in the corporation’s home state.
Unrelated to the forum but nationwide in scope.
Related to the defendant’s forum contacts even if not caused by them.
Based only on internet marketing.

subject: Civil Procedure — Service of Process
body: Mullane v. Central Hanover Bank (1950) established that due process requires what for notice?
options: Notice reasonably calculated to apprise interested parties.
Publication in two newspapers.
Actual receipt of notice by all parties.
Personal service by sheriff.

subject: Civil Procedure — Service by Publication
body: In Rio Properties v. Rio International Interlink (2002), electronic service was allowed when?
options: The plaintiff lacked an address.
Foreign defendants are automatically served online.
Traditional methods were impractical and email was reliable.
The defendant refused certified mail.

subject: Civil Procedure — Pleading
body: Conley v. Gibson (1957) established that a complaint should not be dismissed unless what?
options: No set of facts could support the claim.
It omits citations to precedent.
Discovery has not begun.
It lacks a jurisdictional statement.

subject: Civil Procedure — Pleading
body: Bell Atlantic v. Twombly (2007) retired the 'no set of facts' language and required what new standard?
options: Certainty of wrongdoing.
Summary judgment-level proof.
Evidence before pleading.
Plausibility, not mere possibility, of entitlement to relief.

subject: Civil Procedure — Pleading
body: Ashcroft v. Iqbal (2009) applied Twombly to all cases and instructed courts to do what two-step analysis?
options: Defer to the jury on factual sufficiency.
Ignore conclusory allegations, then assess plausibility of facts.
Review all allegations as true.
Assess intent first, then injury.

subject: Civil Procedure — Pleading Standards
body: Swierkiewicz v. Sorema (2002) held that employment discrimination plaintiffs need not what?
options: Plead a prima facie case under McDonnell Douglas at the complaint stage.
Show probable cause.
File administrative claims first.
Plead with particularity under Rule 9(b).

subject: Civil Procedure — Rule 11 Sanctions
body: In King v. Whitmer (2023), attorneys were sanctioned for filing claims without factual basis. What rule governs this?
options: FRCP 26 — discovery scope.
FRCP 37 — failure to cooperate in discovery.
FRCP 11(b) — representations to the court must be warranted by fact and law.
FRCP 15 — improper amendment.

subject: Civil Procedure — Summary Judgment
body: Celotex v. Catrett (1986) held a movant can win summary judgment by what showing?
options: Filing before discovery closes.
Calling adverse witnesses.
Pointing out the absence of evidence for the nonmovant’s claim.
Proving all elements conclusively.

subject: Civil Procedure — Summary Judgment
body: Scott v. Harris (2007) held summary judgment was proper where what evidence existed?
options: Conflicting evidence existed.
A video record so clearly contradicted the plaintiff’s version that no reasonable jury could believe it.
Plaintiff’s lawyer failed to object.
Multiple eyewitnesses agreed with defendant.

subject: Civil Procedure — Judgment as a Matter of Law
body: Unitherm Food Sys. v. Swift-Eckrich (2006) emphasized that failure to renew a Rule 50 motion after trial has what effect?
options: Preserves issue automatically.
Tolls the deadline for appeal.
Requires en banc review.
Waives appellate review of sufficiency of evidence.

subject: Civil Procedure — Work Product
body: Hickman v. Taylor (1947) held attorney interviews and notes are protected from discovery unless what?
options: Opposing counsel consents.
Substantial need and inability to obtain equivalent information otherwise.
The case involves fraud.
Privilege has expired.

subject: Civil Procedure — Erie Doctrine
body: Erie Railroad v. Tompkins (1938) overturned Swift v. Tyson and held what?
options: Common law governs all tort cases.
State courts must apply federal procedure.
Federal courts must apply state substantive law in diversity cases.
Federal courts create general common law.

subject: Civil Procedure — Erie Doctrine
body: Hanna v. Plumer (1965) distinguished between substantive and procedural law. What governs when a valid Federal Rule applies?
options: The Federal Rule controls if valid under the Rules Enabling Act.
Federal judges use discretion.
The outcome-determinative test applies alone.
State law always overrides.

subject: Civil Procedure — Venue
body: Piper Aircraft v. Reyno (1981) allowed dismissal for forum non conveniens when?
options: The chosen forum is oppressive and an adequate alternative exists.
Service was defective.
The plaintiff’s lawyer is foreign.
The defendant prefers another jurisdiction.

subject: Civil Procedure — Diversity Jurisdiction
body: Hertz Corp. v. Friend (2010) defined a corporation’s principal place of business as what?
options: The nerve center where high-level officers direct control.
Any state with sales offices.
The state of incorporation.
Where the harm occurred.

subject: Civil Procedure — Federal Question
body: Louisville & Nashville R.R. v. Mottley (1908) announced the 'well-pleaded complaint rule,' meaning what?
options: Federal jurisdiction must appear on the face of the plaintiff’s properly pleaded complaint.
Federal counterclaims create jurisdiction.
Any federal defense suffices for jurisdiction.
Jurisdiction is proper if either party raises federal law.

subject: Civil Procedure — Supplemental Jurisdiction
body: United Mine Workers v. Gibbs (1966) allows federal courts to hear state claims when?
options: They were filed in the same year.
Plaintiff demands it.
They share one party in common.
They form part of the same case or controversy under Article III.

subject: Civil Procedure — Supplemental Jurisdiction
body: Exxon Mobil Corp. v. Allapattah (2005) allowed what for supplemental jurisdiction?
options: Aggregation of claims across unrelated parties.
Claims of additional plaintiffs not meeting the amount requirement if one plaintiff does.
Claims from dismissed defendants.
Federal claims to anchor any case.

subject: Civil Procedure — Removal
body: Royal Canin v. Wullschleger (2021) involved removal jurisdiction. When may a case be removed?
options: Whenever the defendant prefers federal court.
At any time after judgment.
When it could have originally been filed in federal court.
If state law claims are weak.

subject: Civil Procedure — Preclusion
body: Painter v. Harvey (1988) discussed claim preclusion. What does it prevent?
options: Reexamination of legal theories within one case.
Appeal of interlocutory orders.
Relitigation of claims arising from the same transaction after a final judgment.
Joinder of permissive claims.

subject: Civil Procedure — Issue Preclusion
body: Parklane Hosiery v. Shore (1979) approved offensive collateral estoppel when?
options: Multiple plaintiffs join.
A criminal case preceded.
It is not unfair to the defendant and the issue was actually litigated.
Plaintiff brings new evidence.

subject: Civil Procedure — Class Actions
body: Wal-Mart Stores v. Dukes (2011) denied certification because what element of Rule 23(a) failed?
options: Commonality — lack of a single common question.
Typicality.
Adequacy of representation.
Numerosity.
